text.p: An angry mob of about 700 villagers in this town in southeastern Mexico rounded up 17 alleged delinquents and burned their homes, local official said on Thursday.
Police eventually rescued the 17 men from the mob on Thursday after 20 hours in captivity. They were turned them over to authorities with the state of Tabasco, officials said.
The assault began on Wednesday when five homes belonging to the 17 men were set afire, witnesses said.
Angry villagers told Reuters they were willing to lynch the men, whom they accused of a series of assaults, robberies, burglaries and the stealing of crops.
"We want justice. We don't want them here," Jose Garica Garcia, elected leader of the community of Indepedencia, told Reuters. Garcia, however, was not a member of the mob.
Independencia is a communal property, or edijo, in the state of Tabasco about 30 miles (45 km) southeast of the state capital Villahermosa. Tabasco is a tropical state near the Yucatan peninsula.
Earlier this year three alleged thieves were taken from their homes, beaten, doused with gasoline and nearly lynched in this corn- and sugar-cane-growing town.
Villagers on Thursday said the band's recent attack on a married couple was the last straw in an alleged crime spree.
After rounding up the 17 men, the mob took them to the centre of town, where a list of allegations was read publicly and the men declared guilty. It was then that police intervened, witnesses said.
Independencia itself is home to about 300 families, but leaders of the mob enlisted the help of angry residents from five nearby communities for the vigilante rampage, Garcia said.
Police took no action against the mob.
